Award.AwardTitle: Pathways to Student Success Initiation Project

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Education and Human Resources

Award.AbstractNarration: The goal of this initiation project is to transform STEM education at FBC by establishing an integrated pathway of learning that will strengthen instructional effectiveness and promote student success. The project will achieve this goal by: (1) initiating an intensive, six-week A?anin-Nakoda STEM Summer Academy for incoming science majors that will prepare them for the rigors of college-level STEM instruction; (2) restructuring existing science curricula to create a new Integrated Science A.S. degree program designed to foster academic excellence and prepare students for greater success in upper division STEM courses and degree programs; and (3) establishing the foundation for implementing a B.S. degree program in Holistic Environmental Science at FBC through curriculum expansion, professional development, and institutional capacity-building. Beginning with pre-college enrichment activities and culminating in a baccalaureate degree program, the project will offer students a continuous pathway of learning grounded in the A?anin and Nakoda worldview and guided by a complementary educational philosophy that encourages students to practice science through cross-disciplinary, collaborative, project-based learning activities and relevant applications. The project?s overall effectiveness will be evaluated in terms of its success in achieving a series of eight student-centered outcomes related to measurable increases in student participation, learning, and success in science courses and degree programs.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The goals of the project are to strengthen instructional effectiveness and to promote student success.  The interrelated objectives are:

~Initiate an intensive, six-week A'anin-Nakoda STEM Summer Acaddemy for incoming science majoprs that will prepare them for the rigors of college-level STEM instruction.

~Restructure exsisting science curricula to create a new Integrated Science A.S degree program designed to foster academic excellence and prepare students for greater success in upper division STEM courses and dgree programs.

~Establish the foundation for implementing a baccalaureate science degree program at ANC through curriculum expansion, professional development and institutional capacity-building.

Recruitment of graduating high school seniors started at the beginning of the academic year and throughout the year.  The Summer academy served as a bridge for college programs, providing enrichment but also focusing on areas of student weakness.  Emphasis was placed upon weaknesses in math skills to give students and understanding the foundations for math.  Introducing students to writing a research paper and different modes of writing techniques; MLA, APA.   Students were introduced to Geosciences, hydrology, climate change, environmental health and traditional plants.  Building students science knowledge skills and interest them in these fields so we can recruit them in potential ANC degree programs. 

Targeting students at a younger grade would be more logical to give them a better chance of encouraging students to take more math classes and recruiting more students into the sciences.  Targeting students would allow the academy to get students "college ready", getting them to think about going to college and what classes they need to enhance their skills to be ready for college courses.

The Natural Resources department developed a Integrated Science degree during 2012/2013, in 2013/2014 faculty worked to expand and modify the degree and revised it to what we call it the Environmental Science Associate of Science Degree.  Upon completion of degree students will be knowledgeable in;

~ using and interpreting scientific explanations (Western and Indigenous) of the natural world

~generate and evaluate scientifc evidence and explanations

~understand the nature and develpment of environmental scientific knowledge in Western and indigenous cultures

~parfticipate meaningfully in environmental scientific activities and discourse.

Along with the general educatgion requirements, students in the major are required to take Environmental Science, Chemistry I, Physical Geology, General Ecology and Natural REsource Management and four electives.  Students can use four electiveds to focus on one of the following options:

~Water/Soil Resources

~Geospatial/Geographical Information System Option

~Traditional Plants

~Science/Pre-engineering.

While there was excitement about the degree there was concern among faculty about students having the necessary background, particularly in mathematics to be successful in these more rigorous courses.  For both this degree and a proposed four-year degree, faulty are clear about the need to build a pipeline of students with the stronger math skills needed for the degree.

Movement towards having an interdisciplinary degree with an environmental focus that would help meet community needs and lead to professional employment for its graduates.  Oner suggestion was for the degree to have somewhat of an environmental health focus - which could be a bridge between public health and environmental sciences.

Faculty do have concerns about the number of students who might enroll in the four year degree program and suggested ways to sustainably work with small numbers of students;

~admit a cohort of students once every several years, the cohort could take classes together and provide support to each other.

~collaborate with other Tribal Colleges to provide needed courses across campuses.

Faculty sees this a a good expansion for the college, but have concerns with sustainability and viability.  And how do they add more courses to their already full load.
